prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal CO10 (PG1302-102)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are designed to detect redshifted CO(1-0) emission from the QSO host. The other three basebands are set up to detect continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary objective of these observations is to detect CO(1-0) emission from a sample of 5 PG QSO hosts. The rms we wish to achieve per QSO host has been determined based on the goal of detecting the equivalent of 1/3 of a Milky Way quantity of molecular gas (~ 1x10^9 M_sun) to at least the 8-11 sigma rms level per velocity channel with moderate (20 km/s for z ~ 0.1-0.2) to low (100 km/s for z ~ 0.2-0.3) resolution. Such a detection goal allows for the flexibility of pushing to higher S/N per velocity resolution element by smoothing the data.
A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.28) of PG 1302-102 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 0.47 Jy km / s. For the adopted line width of 250 km/s (i.e., the average FWHM velocity width for a PG QSO host detected thus far in CO) and a square top CO line profile, a 8 sigma detection corresponds to a rms flux density of 0.24 mJy. Given a velocity resolution of 100 km/s, a per channel rms of 0.24 mJy can be achieved, including calibrations, in 1.1 hours. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 5 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

The primary objective of these observations is to detect CO(1-0) emission from a sample of 5 PG QSO hosts. We will configure the observations using the 1875 MHz bandwidth spectral setup in dual polarization mode. The CO(1-0) line will be placed in either the LSB or USB (depending on the redshift of the QSO), with the other 3 basebands configured for continuum detections. While the continuum may not be detected in the radio-quiet QSO hosts, these data can be obtained at no cost to the primary objectives of the proposal.

We have selected a resolution of 0.45 (= 1.8 kpc) in the OT to allow for the possibility that the CO emission might be extended. For example, if these elliptical hosts are late-stage mergers, we would expect the bulk or all of the CO emission to be contained within the inner 2 kpc of the galaxy. Note that while our sensitivity calculation has been done under the assumption that the emission is not extended, the data can be smoothed up to a resolution of 250 km/s to achieve a better S/N on the CO line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are designed to detect redshifted CO(1-0) emission from the QSO host. The other three basebands are set up to detect continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

For example, if these elliptical hosts are late-stage mergers, we would expect the bulk or all of the CO emission to be contained within the inner 2 kpc of the galaxy. Note that while our sensitivity calculation has been done under the assumption that the emission is not extended, the data can be smoothed up to a resolution of 250 km/s to achieve a better S/N on the CO line.

For example, if these elliptical hosts are late-stage mergers, we would expect the bulk or all of the CO emission to be contained within the inner 2 kpc of the galaxy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the hypothesis that bright UV-excess PG QSOs reside in molecular gas-rich hosts by obtaining CO(1-0) observations of the 5 most luminous, distant PG QSO hosts which were undetected in our z < 0.3 IRAM 30m Telescope survey. Approximately 38% of the hosts were detected, but of the more distant, bright QSOs with high stellar mass hosts, only major mergers were detected. We focus here on QSOs with relatively undisturbed hosts; these hosts are ellipticals or late-stage mergers. Their far-IR excesses favor the latter interpretation, thus they may be the tail-end of the ULIRG-to-optical QSO evolution. These observations, combined with our IRAM data, will enable us to assess the star formation and ISM properties over the full range of host morphologies, and thus place these hosts in the context of ULIRGs and QSOs with prior CO detections. The primary goals of this study are (1) to determine if optically-luminous QSOs, as a class, reside in gas-rich hosts and (2) to assess whether the ISMs of these extreme QSOs are similar to that of local spiral and starburst galaxies by measuring their gas-to-dust ratios.
